title: Steve Brown (darts player, born 1962)
text:
Steve Brown (born July 15, 1962 from <a href="Carshalton">Carshalton</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>) is a former <a href="England">English</a>-born <a href="United%20States">American</a> professional darts player. Who had the majority of his success during the 1990s when he finished third at the inaugural <a href="Professional%20Darts%20Corporation">Professional Darts Corporation</a>'s version of the World Championship in 1994 - after the majority of top players decided to separate from the <a href="British%20Darts%20Organisation">British Darts Organisation</a>.
Career.
During that successful run in the <a href="1994%20PDC%20World%20Darts%20Championship">1994 PDC World Darts Championship</a> Brown beat <a href="Kevin%20Spiolek">Kevin Spiolek</a>, <a href="Keith%20Deller">Keith Deller</a> and <a href="Alan%20Warriner-Little">Alan Warriner</a> to reach the last four before losing heavily 0-5 to <a href="Phil%20Taylor%20%28darts%20player%29">Phil Taylor</a>. He then beat <a href="Peter%20Evison">Peter Evison</a> 5-1 in the third/fourth place play-off, a feature which is no longer staged in the event. Later in 1994, Brown also reached the semi-finals of the PDC Greene King U.K. Masters in Bury St. Edmunds.
Having played league darts from the age of 13, Brown made his debut for the <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a> County 'B' Team (in the British Inter-Counties League) in September 1978. After three years struggling to hold down a team place, he joined the <a href="London">London</a> County squad in 1981, and by 1983, had become established in the <a href="London">London</a> 'A' Team. In 1989 Brown received the great honour of being appointed <a href="London">London</a> Team Captain, following in the footsteps of such illustrious names as <a href="Eric%20Bristow">Eric Bristow</a>, <a href="Cliff%20Lazarenko">Cliff Lazarenko</a>, and Clive Pearce.
His first World-Ranked titles came in 1988 with wins at the Dutch Open and North American Open (which he retained the following year). Another particularly successful year was 1991, when he won the Swiss Open and Darts America, and also reached the final of the French Open, Malta Open and German Open. He was also a semi-finalist at the Belgium Open and a quarter-finalist in the Dutch Open. Despite this success, he never competed at the World Championship until the devastating <a href="split%20in%20darts">split in the game</a>. That was when the PDC (then known as the World Darts Council) field was boosted by a number of North American players who qualified for events alongside the 16 players who had left the BDO to form their own organisation.
He competed at the PDC World Championship each year between 1994 and 2004, but was unable to repeat the form he showed at that first event in 1994 - only reaching the last 16 in 1999 and 2000. His best performance at the <a href="Stan%20James%20World%20Matchplay">World Matchplay</a> came in 2000 when he made it to the quarter-finals but lost heavily to <a href="Ronnie%20Baxter">Ronnie Baxter</a>. 
Brown has also had success on the North American darts circuit reaching several World-Ranked finals including the 1998 Calgary Golden Harvest (losing to <a href="Rod%20Harrington">Rod Harrington</a>), the 1999 Cleveland Darts Extravaganza (losing to <a href="Alan%20Warriner-Little">Alan Warriner</a>), the 2001 Blueberry Hill Open (losing to <a href="John%20Part">John Part</a>), and the 2006 U.S.A. Darts Classic (losing to David Marienthal). He won the 2004 Windy City Open and was runner-up the following year, and most recently won the 2009 Houston Open. In fact, Brown is one of a very small handful of players to have won World-Ranked events in three different decades, and was also the first player to hold all three ADO National Championships simultaneously.
He is also the only American male to be inducted into both the US National Darts Hall of Fame, and the Golden Harvest International Darts Hall of Fame.
Brown lost out controversially on a place at the <a href="2008%20BDO%20World%20Darts%20Championship">2008 Lakeside World Championship</a>. He made it to the semi-finals of the qualifiers in Bridlington - only to lose to <a href="Michael%20Rosenauer">Michael Rosenauer</a> who then beat Swedish player <a href="Kenneth%20Hogwall">Kenneth Hogwall</a> to qualify for Lakeside. Rosenauer had also achieved qualification status for the PDC World Championship and elected to choose that championship instead - thus upsetting those players who he had knocked out of the qualifiers for the BDO version.
After a somewhat disappointing 2008, Brown returned to form the following year. In addition to finishing the year as ADO #1, he claimed a spot on the US World Cup team for the 2009 WDF World Cup which was held in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA. This was Brown's third time on a US World Cup Team, following South Africa (1999) and Malaysia (2001). Brown also came close to qualifying for the <a href="2010%20BDO%20World%20Darts%20Championship">2010 BDO World Darts Championship</a> by way of the BDO Invitational Table, and had he done so, would have been the first American ever to qualify for Lakeside via the rankings.
He competed at the 2010 World Masters, where he lost to Scotland's John Henderson in the third round, and again reached the semi-finals of the BDO World Championship playoffs, losing to eventual qualifier Jan Dekker. Brown finished 2010 ranked as US #1 (for the fourth time) by the ADO. In 2012, Brown was forced to miss a number of major US tournaments, but still finished 11th in the ADO National Rankings. This means that, since Brown's first full year on the ADO circuit (1993), he has never been outside the Top 12 - a run of 20 consecutive years. Also in 2012, he won the Men's Singles at the Blueberry Hill Open for a record sixth time.
Personal life.
Steve Brown lives in <a href="Loveland%2C%20Ohio">Loveland, Ohio</a>, with his wife Missy. His favorite sports are <a href="Motorcycle%20speedway">speedway</a> and <a href="Association%20football">football</a> (soccer) - he supports <a href="AFC%20Wimbledon">AFC Wimbledon</a> - and he also enjoys fishing, particularly catfishing. Other hobbies include cooking, classical music, and visiting cemeteries and graves of the famous. In addition to playing darts professionally, Brown is also involved in darts administration, currently serving as Communications Officer for the American Darts Organization. He had previously served five terms as Area 6 Manager. 
Steve's father, Ken was also a noted darts player during the 1970s, and was the first player ever to play in an official international match. In March 1974, Ken represented a Great Britain (BDO) team which played against the USA in New York. He was first on, beating <a href="Nicky%20Virachkul">Nicky Virachkul</a> 2-1. Ken Brown's best tournament result came in reaching the last 16 of the <a href="Winmau%20World%20Masters">Winmau World Masters</a> in 1976. He also represented England six times (winning five) including a Man-of-the Match performance against Wales in 1978 (his last England appearance), and partnered Sandra Gibb to victory in the Mixed Doubles event in Yorkshire TV's Indoor League.
